content.body: mfreed: I think it would be nice if you or we together drafted a small blog post around the shadow tree changes
content.formatted_body: mfreed: I think it would be nice if you or we together drafted a small blog post around the shadow tree changes

content.body: Regarding trailing (not leading) characters in floating-point number values: Does the parsing algorithm at https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#rules-for-parsing-floating-point-number-values require implementations to ignore all trailing characters that are not ASCII digits?
sideshowbarker: yeah, it ends up ignoring essentially everything at a certain point. Whereas before that it is quite strict.
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: yeah, it ends up ignoring essentially everything at a certain point. Whereas before that it is quite strict.

content.body: That complicates dealing with U+000B… Implementation-wise, it would be easier to just reject it everywhere
sideshowbarker: I left a comment on your implementation. You need to go deeper. :-)
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: I left a comment on your implementation. You need to go deeper. :-)

content.body: The source of the problem is WebKit's (copied by Chromium) string to double operations. They do a bit too much.

> <@annevk:matrix.org> The source of the problem is WebKit's (copied by Chromium) string to double operations. They do a bit too much.

Yeah, I’m discovering that now…
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
The source of the problem is WebKit's (copied by Chromium) string to double operations. They do a bit too much.
Yeah, I’m discovering that now…

content.body: sideshowbarker: It might be a bit much though so not handling U+000B for now would be reasonable too.
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: It might be a bit much though so not handling U+000B for now would be reasonable too.

content.body: * sideshowbarker: It might be a bit much though so not handling U+000B correctly for now would be reasonable too.
content.formatted_body: * sideshowbarker: It might be a bit much though so not handling U+000B correctly for now would be reasonable too.

m.new_content.body: sideshowbarker: It might be a bit much though so not handling U+000B correctly for now would be reasonable too.
m.new_content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: It might be a bit much though so not handling U+000B correctly for now would be reasonable too.

content.body: Ideally string to double would just do the minimal thing. It would progress some character pointer and return failure or a number. And then after that the caller gets to decide whether to ignore trailing characters or not.
And the caller also gets to decide where the character pointer starts (i.e., whether to skip whitespace and what type of whitespace beforehand).
